results.title: Goanna
results.creator_credit: Anna Williams, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Anna Williams’ story is ultimately about empowerment through music. Her uncle, Harry Williams, was a famous Indigenous country musician. Anna tells his story and how his influence and inspiration has helped to empower and heal Williams.

results.title: Little Dolly : Shakira
results.creator_credit: Daniel Edwards, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Daniel Edwards’ little girl, Shakira, was born with Miller-Dieker syndrome, a congenital disorder. Edwards pays tribute to his late daughter, who he affectionately refers to as ‘Little Dolly’.

results.title: Listen up my cherubs!
results.creator_credit: Karen Milward, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Energetic and intelligent, Karen Milward is constantly engaged with life. Often on the road for her work in the Aboriginal community, her children wonder what it is she actually does. This story is by way of explanation and gives insight into the life of an amazing community worker and consultant.

results.title: About Oskie
results.creator_credit: Norman Terrick, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Norman Terrick believes he would not be the man he is today without his father. He lovingly describes a hard working man, who was good at what he did and always had time for his family. Even though he passed away in 1974, Terrick has created this tribute in memory of an inspiring man.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norman Terrick, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Vegetable Growing at Home
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: This short film is a government-produced educational film designed to encourage viewers to grow their own vegetables at home during the Second World War. Produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, the film features a suburban couple who receive a brochure in the mail called ‘Wartime Vegetable Growing at Home’. The educational intent of the film is interspersed with comic scenes predicated on the (now outdated) gender roles of the time as the domestic housewife, Mary, sabotages her husband’s plans to play golf and convinces him to start a vegetable garden. With the assistance of the girl next door, a student at the Burnley School of Horticulture, the hapless husband begins transforming his patch of grass and stops sulking. Moving to an instructional section filmed at the Burnley School of Horticulture, the film’s narrator explains how to dig a patch, turn over and rake the soil, and plant seeds, with the process performed by another expert female gardener (despite clearly being a skilled professional, the narrator mocks her for being a woman). The gardener then demonstrates how to thin out young plants, cultivate the soil and deal with pests, with occasional interludes back to the comic scenes of the domestic couple. Finally, the film shows the rewards of growing your own vegetables, with a bountiful harvest from the garden.

results.title: My university challenge
results.creator_credit: Ray Martin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ray Martin and his girlfriend enrolled in a university course in Thailand to become qualified English teachers. It was here that Martin set himself a challenge that not many people had been successful at achieving.

results.title: Home for four days, gone for four years
results.creator_credit: Sarah Rood, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Sarah Rood retells the whirlwind romance between her grandparents, how they met and the decision to create a life together, against the backdrop of war.
